When they ultimately w~thdrew from the rest of the Jewish nation, the majority of them settled in Sarnaria, along the Jordan, and the rest lived in scattered communities throughout Palestine. Both Flub and Josephns mention them as being very numerous at this time. They were divided into two classes—the first devoting the mae] yes to a life of con - templation, and studying the mysteries of nature and revelation; the second engag - ing in some daily handicraft. They were ruled by a iRabban * assisted by a Rabbi and a IRab, who were chosen by the whole body. In cases of trial, however, a major - ity was required to constitute a tribunij, and the brother who walked disorderly was *Rabban, from the Hebrew ~ master. Rabbi, “ “ “ ‘~, a teacher. Dab, “ “ “ ~j, assistant tea~,hea ‘I o~ccommunicated; yet he was not regarded i~s an enemy, but was admonished as a brother, and usually received back, after due repentance. - They divided the twenty-four hours into three parts: a portion of which was devot - od to the service of God and the relief oF the needy and distressed, a portion to their nanal avocations, and a portion for refresh - ment and sleep. They rose at early dawn and offered up the national prayer for the return of the light of day, after which they betook them - selves to their respective vocations and en - gagements, under the superintendence of the Rabbans and Overseers. At the sixth hour, or twelve o’clock, the labor “~ the Forenoon terminated, and aAl reasb~tnbled, l)athed in cold water, after which they put on their white garments, entered their re - fectory with as much solemnity as if it were the Holy Temple, and sat down together in mysterious silence to the common meal• When seated, the priest invoked God’s bless - iug upon the repast, after which the baker

At the conclusion of the meal the priest offered up thanks to the Bountiful Supplier of all our. wants. This was the signal of their’ dismissal, when they withdrew, put off their white garments, and resumed la - bor again until the eleventh hour (or five o’clock, as we reckon time).. On the.Sabbath they assembled in the synagogues, whei’c they were seated according to their, age, the younger sitting below the elder in becorn. ing attire, and listening.with due attention. Then one takes up the Sacred Volume and reads aportion, whilst a Rabbi expounds. But as they were completely esoteric in their doctrines, they omitted. the most mys - terious~ portions~ which were oniy taught in the ~lladothl;* or place of secret meetings. Fro~ the Mac ca’b~an age’ there was’ a. continuous effort’ among the stricter’ Jews to attain an absolute standard of’ Holiness.. They were divided into three grades, or ranks, and when a candidate applied for admission his character was scrutinized with the greatest severity, and if found worthy, he was admitted to the first grade, when lie was presented with a white gar - ment and girdle. He then remained in a state of probation and trial for one year’, during which time, although lie lived ac - cording to their customs, lie was not ad - mitted to their secret meetings. At the termination of this period he was advanced to the second rank, with its consequent rights and privileges; but he was not ad - mitted to full fellowship with them until after another year of probation, when, if still found worthy, he was advanced to tl~e third rank, and invested with all of the signs, pass-words, and privileges of the Or~ der. On his admission he was reqnired to take 11 upon himself a solemn oath or obligation, the heads of which were as follows To exercise piety towards God and justice towards men; to shun the wicked and emu - late the good; to show fidelity and obedi - ence to those in authority; to be a lover of truth and a reprover of falsehood; to keep his hands clean from theft, and his soul from unlawful gains; to conceal nothing from the Order, nor disclose any of their secrets to any one in any other manner than he re - ceived them himself; and, lastly, to care- frilly guard and preserve the Sacred Books and Symbols belonging to the Order.
